abstract: Read the media rating on a device and determine what media to display on your app.
overview:
## Overview

The parental control app sets the media rating that establishes the parameters of the content the user can view. Your app reads the rating to determine what media to display, so you don’t need to incorporate monitoring with [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/DeviceActivity] or authorize your app through [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/FamilyControls].

### Read the Media Setting

To access the media setting, first create a [doc://com.apple.ManagedSettings/documentation/ManagedSettings/ManagedSettingsStore] object.

This code example identifies the maximum movie rating the user can view on their device. This number can range from `0-1000`. A device that has no predetermined settings prints `1000` to mean all media can be viewed. The number `0` indicates that the user can’t view any movies. To learn more about what each rating means for your app, see [doc://com.apple.ManagedSettings/documentation/ManagedSettings/MediaSettings/maximumMovieRating-swift.property].

While the example above shows how to view the maximum movie ratings, the example can translate to checking the effective maximum TV show ratings as well.

### Monitor the Effective Rating

The parental controls app can change the effective rating at any time. To reflect the changes, make sure to incorporate them into your media app. Use publishers to subscribe to updates on changes to a rating. Managed Settings uses [doc://com.apple.ManagedSettings/documentation/ManagedSettings/ManagedSettingsStore/$effectiveMaximumMovieRating] and [doc://com.apple.ManagedSettings/documentation/ManagedSettings/ManagedSettingsStore/$effectiveMaximumTVShowRating] to publish to media changes.
